0MUa-yF0IyH1jZBxSeydug.text: Delicious. Was intimidating walking in without knowing what anything was, but the person behind the counter let us try a bunch of different things until we knew what would be good. Then they were so kind, and brought us many new things for free to try.   Very helpful, and completely removed any concerns about the first time being in there. Could not have gone better.

JHP4X3LZ8I-V5IHZYdo-vQ.text: The short:  This really is as good as it gets when it comes to turo-turo style Filipino food--reasonably priced, tasty, generous, and authentic. The staff was welcoming, friendly, and helpful.  The long: Located in a big shopping center on the southwest corner of 35th Ave. and Dunlap, the place is fairly easy to find (in the northern arm of the center), and there's ample parking. When you walk in, you see a typical turo-turo style eatery. Turo-turo means "point point," and they use the term because the food is set up cafeteria style, all in a steam table, and all you do is point at what you'd like to eat. You can go for a one-, two-. or three-item combo served with two generous scoops of white rice. There's also a short order menu that serves some Filipino classics, including a whole "silog" menu--which is food served with eggs, usually for breakfast--and some simple American fare like burgers  There were some traditional desserts in the pastry case that served the door and about 16 items in the steam table. My boyfriend and I went for broke because I wanted to see how this food compared to the food I grew up with. We tried the pork and chicken adobo (I'd asked only for pork, but the server didn't like that she couldn't fill a whole 12-oz cup with what was left at the end of the night, she so gave us some chicken adobo in consolation), chicken curry, beef mechado (the sauce is similar to cacciatore--tomato based wit bell peppers), beef kabute (beef and mushrooms, similar to beef stroganoff), laing (stewed taro leaves, what I call the collard greens of the Philippines), and dinuguan (pork in pork blood--not for the squeamish!). The owner also asked if we'd like to try the sinigang, which is a tamarind-based fish soup. To drink we had the sago't gulaman and a mango boba. For dessert (although really, the sago't and boba should be considered dessert for those with a normal, not-homesick stomach capacity), we tried the halo-halo special.   To the point--everything tasted great. If you order on a day your body's really craving protein, you risk suffering death by pork at a turo-turo eatery, and Halo-Halo Kitchen does pork so very well--tender and flavorful. The beef dishes were also well cooked. The curry was pretty standard--the sweeter Japanese style, and the chicken legs in it were also wonderfully tender. The only problems were with the chicken adobo where the sauce was wonderful, but the meat was just a bit dry (you'd think that would be a more common problem in a steam table setup, but because most dishes are stews held at lower temps, the meat stays moist). The laing was more sour than I'm used to--not sure if it was their taro leaves (for the most part, out here, you can only find them frozen or dried), too much fermented shrimp paste (adds a salty, pungent, umami flavor in perfect amounts), or maybe too much patis (fish sauce--adds an earthier layer of the same stuff shrimp paste does), or maybe not enough coconut milk and cream. Regardless, it wasn't bad--just not as sweet as I'm used to. What made the best dishes for me, and what makes Filipino food awesome in my mind, is the sauces. Filipino food is served with rice, and the sauce just soaks into that rice and makes that perfect bite last longer. Because of my choices, we basically ended up with two plates of comfort food, and every bite was definitely comforting.   Our beverages were brought to our table after they were made a few minutes after we sat down, and the halo-halo special came as we finished our dinner. The sago't was good, although the boba grew as the night went on, so sucking it through the straw was crazy. The jelly in the sago't was tasty, though. My boyfriend's mango boba was amazing--at one point, I jokingly suggested they'd just taken some frozen mango and pureed it, but once I said it,  I was halfway convinced that they'd actually done that. The halo-halo special was also awesome. Even though it's considered a summer dessert because it's based on shaved ice, I could eat it year around. It was as good as it gets, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream (it might have been jack fruit ice cream), a generous smear of ube, and a chunk of flat at the top, the sweetened condensed milk soaking into the ice, and the usual halo-halo blend at the bottom (red mung beans, jellies, palm fruit, strips of jack fruit and macapuno, etc.). Halo-halo means "mix-mix," and they set the tall plastic cup up with a dome lid and a long-handled plastic spoon so you could churn everything together into homogenized harmony.   The lady at the counter told us the turo-turo menu changes every day, so I'm looking forward to going back and trying their other food, along with all the other food we didn't have room to try. I love a good silog, and I'm sure I could find it here!

rqdzMX7vua3xtByqI4qVmQ.text: This is a fast food place, not cooked to order. Food is already pre made. I ordered the mungo and pork sinigang. Mungo was a little dry and a tad overcooked but sinigang was real good, just the right sourness. Portions were small but the price was reasonable. Had to order the halo halo and it was really good.

49nFM9Cpx5TAEzvjI8Enlw.text: I would not come back to this restaurant again. The food that is cooked already looks old and don't taste good.  The food is over-priced.  Halo-halo is more expensive that goldilocks.  The leche flan was too little and the scoop of ube ice cream was too small.  And the pancit palabok is 9 dollars...wow!  that's too expensive.  Other restaurants sell it for 5 bucks.  More expensive that goldilocks and the food wasn't even good.

10isRPXscExOgqIqjKjXhw.text: My honest opinion is the food is good. However, there customer service is horrible. In fact it SUCKS! My wife and I are both Filipino and we go there every now and then to see if any thing has changed but to our dismay it's  still the same. When you enter, nobody says hello. We always have to ask for help even though have been standing in front of them for close to 5 min. Employees will just walk by you as if you are not standing there. The owner is this old woman and she is the worst! Doesn't acknowledge you one bit which is something we are not used to. You would think it's almost as if YOU are lucky to eat there not they are lucky to have your business. But on the bright side I have noticed that their customer service is the best thing in the world when you, you're spouse, or just the company you're  with is WHITE. After several experiences like this, we give up and will just stop going there.

zh_8FzuYo5TthK3aBHjO0g.text: I love this place!!  I love filipino food!!  I usually get the chicken adobo, pancit and lumpia...so good!!  I haven't gone back in awhile because of the drive, but I hope to go back soon for some carryout.  Highly recommend to try it!!!  Jason. B

aYsQ7de0YR_sRCG2dNWoXg.text: Maybe not the best idea to go at noon on a Sunday, but I really wasn't paying attention. They were fairly busy, and the line barely crawled. But who the heck cares when they've got slammin' pork adobo, crispy pork belly (call ahead to order, they run out quickly) and garlic rice. Top it all off with a fried egg, and I'm drooling again.

xQjY9cuVFgAqULPIiyqpPA.text: I can hardly write my review because I keep getting sticky hands from this adobo.    The only experience I have with Filipino food was adobo from a fair I went to.  I used to have Filipino coworkers who would always TALK about the food, but when potluck time came around, nothing.  Anyway, the place is small and not much space to move around.  The food is in trays and you pick what you want.    I got the 2 picks and knew I wanted adobo, but asked the guy what else is good.  He gave me pancit which looked like lo mein or something.  Then he asked me if I wanted cantaloupe juice.  It took me by surprise when he pointed to this huge vat of orange, icy, slushiness...I stuttered and said "YEAH!!!" I was about to check out when I saw somebody (I guess one of the owners or family or somethin') putting something in a bowl.  I asked what it was and the heck if I can spell what they said, but it turns out it was some kind of tripe in a white gravy with rice.  Then another guy came and got something that looked awesome as well, which was pork snout.  They gave me a sample of the snout and yeah, the relationship was instant.  Pig nose and me are now friends.  So I have here in front of me is pancit, chicken adobo, pork snout and cantaloupe juice.  I haven't had such a great meal in a while.  All this stuff tastes just as good as I imagined it would when my coworkers would torture me with mouth-watering descriptions of the stuff.  The cantaloupe juicy is unbelievable...I mean the juice of something as delectable as cantaloupe has no choice but to be heavenly, and it is.  I cannot see myself going without it for more than a week.  The adobo is tender and juicy.  The pancit is not dry like I thought it would be, and has a great taste.  The pork snout is just amazing...its got a tang to it that I can't really describe, but also can't get enough of.  I can't remember what it all cost me, I didn't care after I sampled the snout.  But I got a lot of change back from a $20, so...unless it was all 1's then its not expensive.  The people inside were all Filipino and friendly enough to a newcomer.  I've always wanted to connect with my other nationality, and good food is always a great way to do so.  I know I'll be back whenever I can.  And from what I can understand the other side of the place is some kind of entertainment area, and I think one of the other reviewers said its a karaoke thing.  Cool.  Don't be afraid of Filipino food, folks.  Its hard to compare it to other cuisines, especially because I'm not well traveled in the culinary world.  But I would immediately recommend it, even to the guy who only trusts hot dogs and fried chicken.

nCot6_VZJv72XNC1za_-OQ.text: I had the Chicken Adobo with rice, eggs, and tomato. It was good. Service was a little below average, but not bad. Good place to grab a bite and bounce.

_ueo2jIMEvhMU8DOoMuQ6Q.text: For starters...I was never a big boba fan or halo halo fan.  This place is amazing!!  I had a Thai Tea Boba, Let me tell you the bomb digg-addy!!!!  LOL .  Besides there normal Filipino dishes it is a must have.  Then I stuffed my face with Dinuguan, a Filipino savory stew mixed with your typically stomach, intestines, ears, heart and snout of a pig,  simmered in a rich, spicy dark gravy of pig blood, garlic, vinegar, and chili.  SARAP!!!!   ( delish is Tagalog)  along with a side of rice and your good to go!!!!!  Next order to come out was a Lechon (roasted pig) along with the sauce.  Just like my mothers cooking.  I was at home..  Dinuguan is not for everyone, as kids we knew it at chocolate meat, because the sauce is curdled blood which turns dark brown to black when cooked.  The sound of it really "Erks" your stomach, but the taste is out of this world!!!   They have many different dishes all you have to do is "point point"    If you love ethnic cultural world dishes you will appreciate this place.

7AAW_gH_YM9wCE3IiLfN6g.text: Love to eat filipino food? Well this is the best place in arizona to go to. Friendly staff, Tfc channel on, they even have a little mini filipino kiosk selling filipino anything. Love this place

y5zufEZHg11IDBgnDTXeqA.text: The food was good, The prices was a little steep. 10 little pieces of shanghi lumpia for 8.00 are you kidding me?

_f8k8uaAFHVdDyG_Q7GGag.text: Last week I met my family at H2K for dinner.  I enjoyed the dinuguan and sisig with rice and for dessert I shared a Halo Halo with my mom.  I am alway happy after leaving this place:)  I look forward to the next visit!

8-ViiORgQDbqxYmiXBXRFA.text: This was my first authentic Filipino food experience.  The establishment is in a strip mall that looks like any other in the area.  From the look of the "Asian Bistro" sign I thought it was going to be like a PF Changs or a Flo's type of place.  However, upon entering, I could see just how wrong I was.  It is a rather large place and very busy on this Wednesday afternoon.  There were probably only 2 or 3 other daring white people there, so I knew this place was legit.  You walk up to the counter to order kind of like Panda Express in the mall.  You pick a 1, 2, or 3 item combo and they put it on your plate with some rice.  From experience I knew that the 3 item combo would be too much for me to eat, but I ordered it anyway because I wanted to try as much as I could.  I was disappointed that there was no sign describing each of the 12 or so dishes that you could choose from.  Well, if there was, it would probably be in a language that I couldn't understand anyway.  Lets just say I was lucky to have come with 2 Filipino coworkers of mine who acted like guides for me.  I resorted to the "point to whatever looks good" method which worked until I pointed to the bopis (lung) and the dinuguan (blood soup).  More on those later though.  Anyway, I picked the adobo, menudo, and some other beef item.  The beef and the chicken items were good, but I just don't like how they are little pieces that are still on the bone.  I find it difficult to eat and messy.  However, they were very tasty.  My 3rd item was by far the best.  I got the menudo which is more like a beef stew.  Had I known the name of it I probably wouldn't have gotten it because all I had known previously is Mexican menudo and that doesn't interest me.  At any rate it was very good and I would get it again.  Now back to the lung and blood soup.  My coworkers ordered those dishes and of course they made me try them.  I am not going to lie and say that they were terrible because they weren't.  It is just the simple fact that I know what it is and it is way out of my comfort zone so it made my stomach a little weazy.  The best part of the meal here was dessert.  One of my favorite Filipino desserts is called "turon".  It is some sort of banana wrapped in a carmelized wrapper.  All I know is that it is amazing.  My coworkers have brought some to me on several occasions but I just had to have a fresh one right out of the oven.  It was amazing.  They have plenty of other authentic Filipino desserts, but I couldn't resist the turon.  The establishment isn't overly fancy; there are 10-15 large and small tables, a few couches and other misc. chairs.  I think the place doubles as a karaoke bar at night from what I heard.  Anyway, the food is authentic and the service is friendly, but in the end I think my belly is to "Americanized" to dine here on a regular basis.

fpOR40VWYxRTVrfvBEc-xA.text: Went in with a really good and patient attitude. Tried to order SIX things that were on the menu and not available. The air was way down and we spent most of our time cold. Also they charge $1.50 for a very small (plastic) cup of tap water, which they don't tell you about until the tab arrives. I had water and boba and paid $7.50 after a $1.00 tip. The atmosphere and design of the place is my only reason for the single-star rating. The food was mediocre and not very diverse for the price.

LqbmIZdEXXXCKJEx_B3TnA.text: I go there for the longanisa breakfast from time to time and their BOBA.  The place is good but very pricey.  Service is OK not the best and alderly people like to cut the lines to get their orders in and staff does not say anything.  My wife is filipina and says that the food is good.  I had some food catered through them and they were very expensive.  A 1/2 tray of veggies were $49.00.  Way over priced.

p5PZmuvbfYDLUCLxBf3PQw.text: Always The BEST!!! As close as you can get to sitting on Fields ave in pee eye. Great wait staff, friendly people. Great food!! Not too pricy and you will get enough to make you smile later. Friday nights can jump after 7 PM and you can sing and drink pseudo red horse beer and dance if you dare!

DnYw4vPV5TEht52BpKcT3g.text: We live in northern Arizona and whenever we go down to Phoenix, we try to go to Halo Halo Kitchen for lunch to get my Filipino food "fix".  Local filipinos frequent this place (a very good sign!)  The prepared foods are always good and fresh!  Love their pinakbet, mungo beans with spinach and the upo dish!  Love their sticky rice -- not dry like rice at other Filipino and Chinese restaurants!  Always have their special halo-halo (the Best!)  The prices for combination dishes are very reasonable!  When sons of the owners are serving, they are always friendly and very accommodating!

AJeXs3Dq7j02UH7CFbxfBA.text: This is about as anti-chain as you can get. Just what I like! Family ran, authentic. The owner greeted us at the door and explained how the point-point counter worked, even offering some samples of items to help us decide. The blood soup was one of the winners. They just had a great write up in the New Times today that praised them as well. They have whole roasted pigs available for you next family gathering too.

0zeWVTmbvBxhrS1BuVTJRQ.text: I'm on the other side of town from my Filipino Fam, so when I need the comfort food and loving from Titas, I go to Halo-Halo.  The ladies are always so pleasant and welcoming.  Restaurant is always clean, Food is only made with fresh ingredients, and I love taking advantage of watching the Filipino channels while I wait for my food.   The desserts are made with Thrifty Ice Cream, my kids are never disappointed with the Halo-Halo Dessert.   *Sit on the other side away from the cashier, it's a bit warmer from the kitchen* :)

4GzXrCVgg1xMuqI0h6RASA.text: So I didn't have high expectations for this place or any Filipino restaurants because I'd rather be surprised if the place is great. apZvcGI_m2lcVuBGnAznbA.text: I love this place. I don't really crave Filipino food too often but every now and then it happens. On the recommendation of a friend I tried this place out and it is awesome. I felt right at home eating here. The food is authentic Filipino and delicious. I've been just a couple times so far but I don't plan on stopping anytime soon. Satisfy your Filipino food cravings here!

GFBPP34BetaQtqsh8ZnuZg.text: Wow...what happened?!  This used to be a favorite of ours.  It's on the wrong side of town, so we couldn't come here as much as we would have liked.  But it was the best Filipino food in town (except for our house, of course).  But this visit the food was woefully underwhelming.  A poor showing on their part, especially given that we know how good they used to be.  The fresh lumpia was mediocre (at best).  Not prepared properly.  Even my wife thought so, and she loves fresh lumpia.  The Bicol express  was mediocre.  The menudo was mediocre.  The kare kare was OK, not great but OK.  The best thing was a beef and mushrooms dish.  It was ordinary but good.  Maybe they just had an off day?  They were so much better in the past.  Another meal like that and we won't be coming back.

LkqZlU9FYU2-mhwgAzYlfg.text: Portion size was super small. Layout of the restaurant is kind of all over the place. They hardly had anything out. Didn't give much rice with my adobo. I didn't ask them a question but they told me, "We're out of Halo Halo". I don't even like Halo Halo.

PfixvdNFHcztJ4GsxMvDow.text: Living in the West Valley, there's not very many Filipino restaurants nearby.  This is the closest to our house (25 miles away) and I was craving halo-halo so I didn't mind the drive. I was not disappointed! The halo-halo had a lot of toppings and it was very good! So is the sagot gulaman! It was a little sweet but that's how I like it because I just add more ice and water. The food is mediocre. I wish they had more food that is harder to cook at home. I can easily make mechado and adobo at home. I was really craving lechon paksiw but they didn't have any. I think the food is a little pricey but for being the only Filipino restaurant in the area, I'm not complaining. They have some chips and snacks also but it's expensive. Overall, this place is good for my sweet cravings but the food is not worth drive!  Update: I've tried their Turon, biko, Pichi-Pichi, and ube halaya. They were very good! They seriously have the best desserts! The sisig was also very good, but the pork steak was bland and cold.

qUF-w5ZjIILZXIVnupnLow.text: Sisilog I think that's how it's spelled... best breakfast I've ever had in my life.  Was $10. gBOXOsNfO0zAALxPzVr86A.text: We went up to Phoenix a couple of weeks ago to drop off a Forex box and get some lunch here.    We got in about 11 am and got the box taken care of and then looked over all the food on the line.  Maybe 20 selections.  Amazing.  The thing is, Filipino food is pretty simple but very hard to make good.  This place is the best though.  Started getting pretty crowded by noon.  I got the 3-item special which is a lot of food but since we only get up there hardly ever, we got plenty as well as some take home stuff too.  Good food, nice people.  Check it out.  Next time maybe I'll get the sizzling sisig.

NaleVRslJ9d5T91StX15tw.text: I've been here a couple of times - once over a year ago and once recently. I honestly don't remember the first time so this review is specifically my recent experience at Halo-Halo.  I got the Jeprox (fried dried fish) breakfast for $8 on a Saturday morning. They actually didn't have this out on the menu, but I asked and they were awesome enough to make it for me since it wasn't busy when I stopped by. For $8, I felt that the serving could've been larger, but the food itself was still delicious for Filipino food standards in Phoenix.   I also got some treats: the ube halaya and sans rival (sylvana). The ube was good but the sans rival, for a price of $2.50 per piece, was extremely overpriced and honestly not worth it. Overall, I'd come back here again and try the main dishes next time.

The pansit was fresh and they gave me a very large satisfying portion. The adobo was flavorful and had so much I had made adobo fried rice for breakfast the next morning. EO0Hp41Hmu2JTHDeRCTphw.text: Amazing pork Sisig! If you love Mexican food you will love this place. Even if you don't have a Filipino GF to drag you here. Hahah. Oh she's picky on her Filipino foods.

yKHhiRJJ8MY5cNDA76-qMQ.text: I'm going to start off by stating that I've only had Filipino food a couple of times before so I'm not the best critic, however, based on everything that we got, I'm going to rate Halo-Halo Kitchen 3 stars.  When we walked into the restaurant, we got into line to order food cafeteria-style. They had one, two, and three item plate options, each served with two scoops of rice, as well as a few options that were made-to-order. I recognized a couple of the made-to-order items (lumpia & pancit) but didn't really know what the other items they had were. Because they were super busy, I made a quick decision of ordering the Adobo Chicken. Per recommendation of the gentleman who was making our plates, my fiance got the Boneless Bangus.  The Adobo Chicken had a lot of different spices & broth that could be eaten with the rice. I didn't like how fatty the pieces of chicken were but the flavors in the dish were unique. This one item plate was $5. I only had one bite of the Bangus but it was crispy & it too was seasoned with unique spices. I'd probably recommend that over the Adobo Chicken. This fish counted as a two item plate for $7, and came with a side of soup broth as well as rice.  As I mentioned at the beginning, I've not had much Filipino food, but I found everything we got very vinegar-y. As a result of that, I didn't finish my plate of food, but while eating I saw someone else adding vinegar to their food so maybe it's suppose to be that way.  I thought it would be a good idea to get some Halo-Halo Special to round out the meal. They definitely served up an interesting & tasty version treat ... I'd get it again! Just because of how far this restaurant is, I probably wouldn't drive out of my way. If in the area, I'd think about stopping by to try other items since the food is inexpensive.

photos.caption: Photo of Halo-Halo Kitchen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Bangus fish.
Photo of Halo-Halo Kitchen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Adobo Chicken.

mqLyA_RjV4tW8RfrK2zF9Q.text: It actually should be a 1.5* but it's Sunday so...I'll go ahead and round up. I suggested to my boyfriend to take me to this restaurant because of the good reviews and the pictures of the food and halo halo looked amazing.   So we get there about an hour before they closed on Saturday. No one was there except for us. It was set up like a Chinese fast food place where you go up and tell them what you want and they scoop it up for you. We ordered the 3 item meal which was $14. It came with rice and we ordered lechon kawali (roasted pig), paka [something, I forget the name] (pork stew) and pork adobo.  The roasted pig was dry - it's probably because we came close to closing and the food was sitting under heat lamps all day. The pork stew was made from the pork hock - this was greasy and full of bone. The lady scooping this out for us scooped a lot of bone into our bowl. I wouldn't gripe if the bone was attached to meat.... this was straight bone that's fallen off the bone. The pork adobo was not bad but it was also greasy. If you're on a diet - you won't want to get most of their items.   We also ordered the halo halo especial - it wasn't that special. It was basic and boring in flavor. My boyfriend liked it but I didn't care for it.   This place was not particularly close to our home so we will more than likely not be coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Halo-Halo Kitchen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Everything except the rice was greasy!

vUgT3EOr0cZv92tE0DREZA.text: This place is legit with their Filipino food. Everything we ordered was tasty and flavorful. I tried the lechon kewali which was on point with the crispness of the skin. The pork bbq stick was also good.  The wife tried a breakfast platter of garlic rice,  tocino, and fried egg, which were all good. Two of the kids tried the spam sliders and fries which were all good. One of the girls went to town on the chicken adobo over rice.  Mom in law tried the diniguan, which she said was good.  For dessert we tried the halo halo special which was super good. Girls tried the ice cream which was all good.  One of them also tried the boba which was also good. Service was excellent. The staff was friendly. They have a couple large screen tv's playing sports.  Overall an awesome experience with some great tasting food.

3JRIWNqHp6RIZ_Eqpl1tOg.text: This place is awesome and super clean ...I will keep coming back EVERYTHING is sooo good here AND the price won't break your wallet. So go enjoy some good Filipino food!

MA1BpRLKdwAHFMvKc_r_uw.text: If I could give zero stars I would. After reading the reviews and calling another Filipino restaurant closer to our home my family was sold on getting a whole lechon from here for my daughters first bday. From the moment we put in the order it was not a pleasant experience. We were told that they could deliver to a park in chandler were the party was being held, then minutes later they changed their mind and told us they wouldn't deliver it. On the day of the party we had set up the lechon and it was just not at all what we had expected. The skin was not crispy at all as it should've been traditionally. It was just soggy I guess is the best way to describe it. Having hyped it up to guests that they would be having a traditional Filipino dish that was crispy and succulent, it was embarrassing! My mom called the restaurant that day to complain and the wife of the owner told my mom that he would call her back, of course they didn't. So my mom called back today and spoke to Brandon, I think was his name. He said that they couldn't guarantee that the lechon would be crispy, which I think is ridiculous! If you as the customer are going to spend $320 for a dish that is traditionally crispy, then that is what you should get. Brandon also stated that he had seen that it was soggy when preparing it and that out of the three lechons they had prepared that day ours was the only non crispy one, so why did we get so lucky to receive that one. Hmm. He did offer to give half off the next lechon purchase, but why would we want that when this experience was none to pleasing, and anyways it was for a party it's not like we would want to eat a whole lechon on some random day.

jG-AeBToD6Q9pd22-PVMqw.text: Since there aren't that many Filipino restaurants in AZ, lets just say that Halo-Halo kitchen is the place to go. Great tasting food at a good price. The portion size is great as well. Highly recommended!

vEeDG-oEj9JbM7mc19CJsg.text: Best lumpia in Phoenix and an all-around authentic restaurant. Well worth the drive.

BUAH5XAy0X6tl2woUxZEjA.text: As Filipinos coming from California, we definitely have access to Filipino food vendors.  That being said, we are always up to delving into local businesses to enjoy their creations.  We were passing through Phoenix & decided to lunch here.  Place is cleaner than a lot of CA vendors and standard TFC playing on the tele.  Service is friendly. Prices appropriate.  Didn't have to wait too long for breakfast plates to be prepared, better fresh anyway, rather than it sit there all day waiting to be served. We sampled a few items: KARIOKA: WWhaaatt!??!  Those lil delights are a rare find, but they got 'em here!  Tasty too!  A perfect crisp to the shell & soft inside. 4 per stick, shoulda bought more! EMPANADA:  deep fried goodness! Tasted freshly cooked, not too doughy, an ample amount of contents inside. HALO-HALO SPECIAL:  Hot DAMN!  MASARAP!!!!  Oh so good!  This has got to be my new favorite place for halo-halo & I don't even live in the state! They do their namesake proud! LONGSILOG: My kids devoured this!  Ordered 3 of these & had no leftovers among 3 boys.  SISIGSILOG: I like my sisig with the chichiron-esque crunch & juicy meat.  This was the rubbery cartilage type cooked well. Not my favorite but good for this type of sisig.  We were hoping to try the torta talong but they ran out, must be good. Next time nalang. Great place, wish they operated in Cali!

BOmKtO4Ew1FHEFgsCUG6-Q.text: I really, really liked this place! I tried it for the first time today since my neighboring Filipino restaurant I wanted to try SUCKED! (They didn't have anything and had horrible customer service) I'm glad that happened since it led me to this place. I'm half Filipino and can tell good Filipino food. I tried the pancit, chicken adobo, lumpia, fried pork skin, and halo-halo. All were like my grandmothers cooking and I was pretty impressed! I felt very comfortable in the atmosphere. The young girl at the counter was very helpful with my initial order and so was the younger guy helping me later. I liked that it felt like a family owned and ran kinda place. I will be returning here to try their talapia, panakbit, sinigang, and tocino, this is well worth my 30 min drive to get there.

dIY_eq0THh_Uj2-pw2vhGg.text: I wish i could give 3-star for this fil resto but my experience with my order of pancit bijon last new year's eve made me think otherwise... I picked up my order on dec 31 late pm... We ate for new year's eve and kept in the ref like 2/3 of the tray... I heated the left-overs for our jan 1 lunch & i was disappointed to find it spoiled already... Normally i dont complain but I threw like $29 of the $45 cost i paid for this pancit... I was just wandering how come it did not even last a half day... Working in a food business for 36 yrs, i tried to determine what it might cause... Maybe becoz they packed the pancit while it was very hot (i got it fully wrapped with no holes on it)...or it was cooked early or by batch... It started in the vegetables they mixed with the pancit coz i smelled every single ingredients in the bijon... I called the resto to tell them my experience & all i got was "i will tell the manager" response... No sorry at all... Better review on the cooling process & wrapping orders & teach your people how to deal with customer feedback... Not a good way to end 2015 & start 2016 with a complaint... :(

vgSWX_Pjf7vMPcdnf7jU6A.text: Just an FYI, not sure how long ago but I think pretty recently, this place has new owners. It is now called Halo Halo Kitchen aka H2K.   My mom was born & raised in the Philippines, so she was pretty excited to come here for lunch this past Thursday afternoon.   She quickly got to talking to the guy behind the counter & another customer to see what was good here. She decided on about 7 different items for her, my dad & myself to try. My personal favs were the fried tilapia, chicken adobo (although, my mom's is better!), lumpia, pancit & this fried egg & pork combo that I can't remember the name of. Oh & they also had this dessert which was little round balls on a stick made from what smelled/tasted like doughnut batter. There was a sweet syrup on top with what tasted like coconut on the inside. They were lick your fingers delicious!!   We'll definitely be back :)

k8k2gwcJ-5mRGV6u-UVc-g.text: Food was okay....a bit pricey though for their selection.   Lechon kawali was fresh. roomie ordered French fries ; he said they were stale.  We ordered the shrimp platter and it took over 25 mins to arrive.

3fFcTwUOE_pokMBUTv13Bw.text: You know that part of the movie in Ratatouille where the chef starts crying because the food brings him back to his childhood....that's halo-halo kitchen for me. Living in Phoenix, far away from my mom in Oregon, filipino food is hard to come by. I make the 30 min drive from mesa just to eat here when I start going through withdrawals. I've had pretty much everything they've serve here. The restaurant is clean, people are friendly. It's a typical "turo-turo" restaurant, where the food is prepared cafeteria style but it's all good.

4cmGmEGxj6XaB5gdA98FJA.text: the food was good. i like the way the cooked my fav diniguan hahaha. they have all day breakfast...

_MFUk-rZoxbGCsh5eNeTDg.text: I recently become aware of Halo Halo.  They had my very most favorite dish.  The name has always escaped me.  It has a pork blood base, served with rice.   The first time I had this it was from an in-formal kitchen.  I loved it, it was sole food at its best.   I have had it serval times sence, each time it was different, but just as good and comforting.   There has been times the Filipino server informed me I didn't want that, I would not like it.  This is why, not the pork blood base but the organ meat (offal) and the miscellaneous tidbits or trimmings that was part of it.  It was not made with the best parts, but the leftover parts.  Some times it was a mildly spicy, that is the regional and cooks preference, never hot or more then mildly spicy.  As I had it in the past it had all kinds of notes or tastes, do to all the different bets that went into it.  Sadly, regrettably, and a statement on the narrow minded, American Eaters, in order to serve to "the American" customer (to stay in business), this wonderful dish has been turned into a good but 2 note meal.  They use standard pork, one note, the sauce note 2, rice is the binder the same as FOFO, bread, and other starchy foods.     I pity all those that will not even try anything other then Midwest American washed foods.   You think that the Asian food you eat is real Asian, it is American Asian.   Many Asian restaurants have two menus, one for us, the other for the Asian taste.  That menu is call a head.  Sooooo much better, but not steak and potato's.   I hope that Filipino restaurants will do the same thing, so that people can have the True taste of home and strange people, such as I, can enjoy as well.     ITS NOT THE LOOKS, NOT THE NAME, NOT WHAT GOES IN, BUT THE TASTE.

udERXhnfGr_WDJVgaXzozg.text: This is the best Filipino Restaurant in Phoenix!  The restaurant is nice and always clean.  The staff there are friendly.  The food is reasonably priced.    They offer a lot of variety each day.  I believe they offer around 15+ entree options and that's not including their silog menu.  My fiance and I usually get a two choice with a boba drink and that usually comes out less than $20.  If we're really hungry we get a halo halo supreme to finish our meal.

L1FHqPX20A12JdlSXd5T0Q.text: The food was great and very inexpensive. They advertise happy hour 4pm-7pm but were told there is no happy hour. That was the reason for missing star. I will go back.

yS4oIGbiRa9vL0eVAbulKg.text: This is my ultimate favorite place to go for Filipino food!! For special occasions, we often order the lechon and it's always amazing!  I don't live near the restaurant but I usually make the drive for the crispy pata, tapsilog, and occasionally their beef mami! So much to try here and the customer service is always on point!!!

dqXmX9kgyaavroTg_YOGNQ.text: I'm definitely a fan.  We were visitors to Phoenix and came here as a big group last Friday afternoon for a late lunch.  As someone who lives in the Midwest eating in a Filipino Restaurant is always a treat and coming to Halo-Halo Kitchen was definitely a super treat!  It is located in a strip mall but don't be put-off by the location. There's nothing fancy about the place but you can tell the owners take measures to keep the place clean and neat.  They have a karaoke bar like most Filipino restaurants do.  You can order a la carte but probably the best way is the "pick-and-point (turo turo) way" which is typical of most Pinoy restaurants.  That way you get to sample a better variety of foods.  You get a choice of 2 entrees plus rice.  I had the kare-kare( beef in peanut sauce) and coconut chicken, while my wife had lechon kawali and ginataang langka (coconut jackfruit).  The food was just flat-out awesome. No other way to describe it.  Then we had halo-halo for dessert.  Wow! That was so good, too!  Loved it.  Our friends all enjoyed their entrees and we continued to talk about the food that weekend.  We enjoyed our whole visit to Phoenix that weekend but think this was our gustatory highlight of the trip.  We're definitely coming  back when we visit Phoenix again.

n_YaLyr_6_3gVcAffWDMqA.text: Setting:  I went here 3 times this past week.  Being the last week of school, we had a couple potlucks.  Therefore, nothing says my Filipino culture than bringing some deep fried goodness of egg roll called Lumpia.  They were good enough to bring my wife here for dinner.  Ambiance:  It looks like any other typical Filipino restaurant, but wait...there's a karaoke bar!  Wait, did you say magic mic?  Why yes I did.  They have a full blown karaoke machine they play on Friday nights.  I have not experienced it, but one of the workers say it is definitely a fun night.  Boy, us Filipinos sure love our karaoke!  Open seating with the definite Filipino feel.  After growing up in Southern California, this looks and smells like a Filipino restaurant to me.  Food/Menu:  Lumpia - shanghai style, about 3 inches long, with a good amount of filling.  Crispy, yet not too deep fried.  Very good egg rolls though.  Halo Halo - a Filipino dessert with shaved ice, condensed milk, red bean, canned fruit, ube (sweet purple yam), and ice cream.  They do a decent job.  However, from my perspective, I don't think I have ever had a bad Halo Halo, as most taste the same to me.  Turon - a deep fried plantain banana.  Need I say more?  Okay, well it has a great caramelize coat around it with the crunch biting into a sweet plantain banana.  And BAM!  You got dessert.  Empanada - Tasty snack that will definitely fill you up...for wanting more!  Service:  Seems family owned and they take care of their shop.  No complaints!  Overall:  With the limited amount of Filipino restaurants compared to where I grew up in Southern California.  This place hits home in all the right areas.  Whenever we need to taste our culture, we will be back Halo Halo!

66f8m45Z8yhj5BR1PmQNhw.text: Awesome place and great people that work there. If you run into them while partyin in Scottsdale...they'll even feed you

IZ6Q5BskU9PC-FCbtTAR2w.text: TL;DR (out of 5): In a state with very little cultural/culinary diversity, I was surprised to find the Southeast Asian hole-in-the-wall restaurant that is Halo-Halo Kitchen.  With a variety of traditional options from silog to full entrees to fun snacks and drinks, Halo-Halo has brought the Filipino dinner table to central Phoenix.  Although the oily, diet-overlooking fare isn't for everyone, it's definitely on my list of go-to's in PHX. Food: 3 Atmosphere: 3 Price: 4 Service: 4 Decor: 2  I gave this restaurant 4-stars overall even though my experience with the food was more deserving of 3-stars due to the fact that I went into the restaurant around 4:30 after skipping lunch.  Unsurprisingly, the food (served in a Panda Express-like fashion) was not the freshest. I ordered the 3-combo plate , which comes with two scoops of rice, and chose lechon kawali, chicken adobo, and pork dinuguan (pork and pig's blood stew).  The lechon, which I had heard so much of, was understandably sub-par, due to the fact that it had probably been sitting under a heat lamp for quite some time.  The meat was flavorful and tender, which was my main expectation.  However, the fat was not soft enough, and the skin was not crispy; they were both relatively chewy.  I would expect that a fresh order of lechon kawali would have been much better.  The sauce that it came with was nice, although I'm guessing it's essentially a reduction of the pan drippings from the pork with vinegar and other flavors - but good nonetheless.  The chicken adobo was jam-packed with flavor.  There was a peppery-ness and sweetness that balanced really well.  The chicken itself was falling off the bone and the bones themselves broke apart when I bit into them (although I'm unsure as to whether or not that's a good thing).  I was hesitant to order the dinuguan because it looked quite heavy, but was pleasantly surprised to find that the heaviness of the pork blood was counteracted by the tanginess of both vinegar and banana peppers in the stew.  The pork meat itself wasn't half bad, but I think it had been cooking for a little bit too long as it was kind of tough.  Overall, the food was little too oily for my liking (even for Southeast Asian food) and the foods were a little too saucy, but the flavors were all there.  And like I said, for a hole-in-the-wall Filipino restaurant in central Phoenix, Halo-Halo is doing pretty darn well.  The atmosphere was fine - since I went in at a weird time, the restaurant was essentially empty.  The mom and children who shuffled in after me seemed quite excited to be there, so that's a good sign.  The decor was unsurprising for a hole-in-the-wall Filipino restaurant; very similar to a mexican restaurant, there were cheap tables and chairs organized randomly in dining area with red tile and decorations galore.  I didn't really expect too much in terms of the restaurant's aesthetic from the get-go.  The woman who boxed up my food for me was nice though; she explained what each of the options were and seemed happy enough to be there.  3-entree plate: $10  - rice  - lechon kawali  - chicken adobo  - dinuguan  Next time, I'll have to try their fresh lechon kawali and maybe their silog.  I'm sure that ordering a taro smoothie or something of that sort would also help to cut through the heaviness of their food.

rVFK6Wdtryh3mkqkzQ45lw.text: First I gotta say I always made fun of Filipino food cause it all looks the same and kept calling it Mud. I have a lot of Filipino friends and they live by this food/mud so I decided to have an open mind when I came here to try it out.   Let me tell you the tastes looks better than it looks. But of course not everything looks like mud. I found out they have awesome sizzling hot plates of stuff called sisig which has an egg. Also simple plates dishes with the red looking meat called Tocino. It's so flavorful and perfect with the veggies rice and eggs.   Everything is perfect for either breakfast lunch or dinner so when you come here you can eat whatever you like.   I also enjoy how this place is family owned and run so you get that homey feeling, and they have a bunch of tvs. If you're Filipino they play Filipino shows during the day but I've also seen them showing sports.   Now if you're a drinker they also have a bar, now you would think they would have basic liquor they don't they got everything from well vodka to like 25 year old glenlivets. All Johnny walkers all types of premium vodka and the lists goes on. Oh don't forget the beer, thy got the basics as well but they have a lot of other unique beer like red horse which tastes great if you haven't had one try it.   Now they have some awesome baked goods which are baked fresh everyday. And you must try HALO HALO which they are known for, it's a Filipino dessert filled with deliciousness.

YTIFCBoRo3Bysj4oOvCoXw.text: This Filipino Food was very good and I think most people can find something they like here because we tried three different meats and a tofu dish and all were different all were cooked nicely with good developed flavor. Nothing was spicy or aggressively seasoned and nothing tasted Chinese or Thai that I tried to me but everything we tried had a rich developed flavor. Portions are large prices are very low I think our combo plates were about $6.99 each.  This place is VERY CASUAL and is set up sort of like Panda Express. You decide on the kind of plate you want just like at Panda and point to what you want on your plate by looking at the food line or you can order from the pictures on the wall. Next you pay and seat yourself and clean up your tray when you leave.   I picked a combo plate so I could try two things. I picked Coconut Chicken and Tofu with vegetables. Both my picks looked familiar like Chinese or Thai dishes to me but neither of them had the seasonings I thought they'd be but the food was still tasty and good. The Chicken was very moist and had great developed flavor from being slow cooked on the bone but they didn't brown the skin so I found the skin unappetizing and had to remove it. That is my only criticism.  My husband tried the pork adobo and one of the beef dishes. He said both were very tender and tasty and he'd come here again.  This was a fun adventure it was like traveling the world.

6_zMj4qAuZdhzizcDI9oIw.text: Being a San Diego native living here in the Phoenix area, I was very hesitant to try any Filipino restaurants. This place was actually pretty good, especially the Lechon Paksiw and Dinaguan. My daughter also ordered their Special Halo Halo and that was good too. We will definitely be coming back here when we get lazy to cook Filipino food.

9uVf3aIFsylcbS2sXh3ukA.text: I love their sizzling sisig, pork sinigang, kare-kare, lechon kawali, and leche flan! There are two reasons why I don't give them 5 stars. First, I don't like their service AT ALL. There were two employees and they were talking when I'm about to buy their leche flan and they didn't stop at all. They didn't even say thank you.  Second, when I call ahead to get an order ready, they say that they're gonna get it ready. But they never do. I always have to wait when I get there.

IzbHc8LaM9YvwVZfh23fTA.text: I was happy to see that a Filipino restaurant was nearby and we have been here three times and that will be our last. I'm all for giving second and third chances, but this place is not a 5 star customer service friendly place. It's not busy and yet, we don't get acknowledged by the lady behind the counter. When she did see us and finally looked up,  she had a frown on her face. No hello or can I help you. The customer in front of us was asking another a different server a question and wasn't acknowledged. I had to tell her what the foods were and ingredients. While we were waiting for our lumpia, the servers changed their moods and was friendly to a new customer that walked in, must have been a regular. The food was so so, dry meat and greasey sauces. It's best to learn these recipes myself.  One thing for this restaurant to consider,  be kind to ALL customers and not just the regulars. Believe it or not, new customers are essential to a sucessful restaurant. Especially when they can post reviews or advertise by word of mouth.

Dna-0JjSD2b-YJebufOiJQ.text: This place is AUTHENTIC!!!  If you're looking for someplace fancy with servers this is not the place for you.  But if you're looking for authentic filipino food, then this is the spot!    The pancit was awesome, all the "silog" plates (meat option, garlic fried rice, and eggs) are great!  The pork adobo was just ok, but I'm super partial to my own families adobo.      This place is kinda like a filipino panda express where they have prepared food that you can point at and choose.  They also have a menu you can order from though if you want something not already prepared.    BONUS: They also have some snacks and goodies that you can buy to take home!

nkeNkRB1gzatkLdPrcedQg.text: This place is one of the best Filipino restaurants I've been to. Completely authentic. Came here during Super Bowl weekend 2015. Was one of the highlights of my trip. Coming from Boston where there are hardly any Filipino restaurants, I was desperate for some Lechon Kawali, Lumpia Shanghai & Pancit Bihon. I was pleasantly surprised at how good the food was. Lechon perfectly cooked with meaty portions & crispy skin. Was tempted to go back the next day on Super Bowl Sunday but had tix for game & didn't want to get caught in traffic. Looking for an excuse to come back to Phoenix...

The food was so bad that I even considered that McDonald was where better than this place... that says alot!!!

1XhCxi1epCM4pHOYrC9GSQ.text: I'm an out of state Filipino college student & this place is perfect for me every time I miss home cooked meals! They lay the food out & they have quite the variation. My favourites, hands down, are the pork menudo, pork adobo & dinaguan! Everything there is delicious though! Their 3-plate entree is just 10$ & the portions are decently sized! You can also buy Filipino snacks & ice cream too. The owner is hella cool too & friendly to chat with. (I'm a Seahawks fan, he's a 49ers fan). Definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants to try or loves Filipino food. You get all the foods for all the flavours & no work! :)

eJvJkqx3vb-VMmvDVY43RA.text: Was craving for Filipino cuisine sknce haven't had any since I arrived so tried this one out... Food is authentic Filipino flavor. I liked their halo-halo the most. The owner made my companion try out a few dishes since it was her first time to be in a Filipino Restaurant but I thought the owner was reluctant and unwelcoming.  It could be easily shrugged off but for one who takes service and taste/ flavor of high value, it couldn't be one or the other.

RJqqonuth5BIukitwzTrFQ.text: Good tasting food but chincey small overpriced portions. Paid $9.00 for a 2 item plate. I asked server for half rice/pancit. Server removed half my rice said $1.00 extra, no problem. She barely gave me a spoonful of noodles and 1ice cream scoop of rice. My wife wanted pancit instead of rice on a 1 item plate and was told $1.00 more, again no problem a different server removed the one small scoop of rice and added barely a serving spoon of noodles. I looked at my 2 item plate $9.00 and asked for another scoop of rice as I was hungry and plate was anemic and told .50 more!!?? I passed,  I have been eating Filipino food for last 30+ years in a variety of Filipino Establishments from HI to LV and never been treated to such skimpy tight wad portions or up charges for noodles w rice. $16.00 for lunch = 1 2 item plate and 1 1 item plate w 2 ice waters. I have eaten at this location a couple times prior and never had issues with portion control, will probably NEVER return. Not worth the frustration, hassle w server or cost.

PpTIorJ3vP09Bo4-rZIpSg.text: The fried pork skins were great. The sauce that went with them, great.  The pork adobo, awesome. The halo-halo, great.  Overall, great.   They even served us just before they closed (our bad).

Y2PnABdKryfbqtv4yCxYaw.text: As it worked out, I was house sitting in the area and was craving something different. Since it was my first time, I was a little confused about how the ordering process worked but I joined the line of fellow patrons and placed my order for the second breakfast of the day: the spamsilog! When was the last time I've had Spam?! Too long. This was perfectly griddled and served with over easy eggs and a great serving of rice. I would definitely go back the next time I'm house sitting for another of their offerings.

5NuRMpNjsLEeaJzOeZYH8Q.text: First time ever for Filipino food and we were not disappointed. Quick counter service or you can order from the grill. Hubby had the spam & eggs with garlic rice. The spam was crisp-fried, the eggs were perfectly over-easy, and the garlic rice was tender and flavorful. I had the coconut chicken (brothy/creamy) over white rice. It was a little bit sweet and a little bit savory. Some of the chicken pieces were still on the bone, so even though they are bite-sized, be careful. Clean, super clean bathrooms, and friendly service. Good prices too. We'll be back for sure.
